question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will create a red team and green team structure inside the project. The green team optimises for making Agro-Park alignment work, while the red team looks for flaws and prototypes community-led workarounds. They meet monthly to stress-test plans in a war-game format, and the resulting experiments form a portfolio of contingency innovations that can be deployed if the primary alignment pathway fails.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will treat the different regions as natural experiments in alignment. For example, one region might prototype full Park integration, another might treat the Park as an anchor for post-conflict markets, and a third might build an independent co-operative federation that sells partly to the Park. Comparing these regional models will generate real-world evidence on which balance of alignment and autonomy works in which context.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will establish a community–Park negotiation simulation as a recurring practice. Using results from village experiments as bargaining chips, groups will regularly role-play price negotiations, quality disputes, and contract changes, building both their negotiation skills and our understanding of which experimental results actually increase leverage in real alignment talks.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will use anticipatory governance experiments that start from communities’ fears about the Park, such as land grabbing or environmental damage, and then run proactive pilots in land documentation, community by-laws, or water monitoring to pre-empt those risks, making future alignment safer and more just rather than blindly optimistic.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will allocate a portion of the budget as a policy hedge fund that explicitly supports experiments built on the assumption that the Agro-Park may fail or be exploitative. If the Park succeeds, the hedge was unnecessary but the main strategy wins. If it fails, communities already have alternative models tested and ready, which is a systemic form of risk management.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will design some experiments as Trojan horses. For instance, a technical trial on soil amendments might be run entirely by a landless women’s group, thereby quietly building their governance capacity and de facto land access. These embedded social innovations build more equitable structures from within activities that look innocuous to the formal system.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will run regular policy stress-test sprints. Each quarter we will take one specific Park requirement, such as digital traceability, and run a short, intensive village sprint to see how communities can realistically meet it using their own ideas. The outputs are friction maps and community-generated compliance protocols that inform both our support package and feedback to policymakers.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will experiment with different narratives about the Agro-Park in communities, such as seeing it as a jobs hub, a guaranteed market, or a risk that needs managing, and trace which narrative leads to the most constructive innovation. We will then use that narrative frame deliberately to shape and target further experimentation and engagement.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will structure our work in divergence and convergence cycles. In divergence periods, villages are encouraged to pursue bold experiments without worrying about policy, while in convergence periods we convene communities and Park planners to review what came out and choose which ideas can be adapted and integrated, avoiding constant, shallow compromise.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will treat the Agro-Park as just one customer for village innovation rather than the only horizon. We will support communities to develop their experiments into prototype products or services that could sell to the Park or to other markets, making alignment a business decision rather than a dependency.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will create a joint reality-check council with equal representation from Park planners and community experimenters that meets regularly. Experimenters present unvarnished results, planners present real constraints, and together they identify the adjacent possible next step that moves toward alignment without denying the evidence from the ground.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will use backcasting from a vision of fair, successful Park integration. Starting from that desired end-state, we will ask what capabilities and arrangements must already exist in five years and then design experiments now that specifically build those missing pieces, so that local innovation is tightly linked to a positive alignment scenario.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will identify and train community members as policy hackers who enjoy reading official documents and spotting loopholes or flex points. Their role is to design experiments that legally exploit these openings for community benefit, turning alignment into a creative, rules-based game rather than a one-way imposition.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will not try to balance policy and experimentation as separate things; we will dissolve the dichotomy by convening a constitutional convention for the Agro-Park itself, where village experimenters, Park planners, and traditional leaders co-draft the Park’s founding charter. Experimentation then becomes the method for writing and revising the rules, and alignment is redefined as fidelity to an evolving, co-created social contract.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will make the Agro-Park the experiment by proposing it as the world’s first explicitly anticolonial Park, whose primary success indicators are the transfer of land equity, governance seats, and intellectual property to communities. Village-level experimentation then becomes the research and development arm of this reimagined Park, not a side show to a fixed model.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will use the logic and resources of the Agro-Park to finance communities’ ability to exit from it on their own terms. While we engage the Park process, we will focus experiments on building parallel, community-owned infrastructure in processing, finance, and data so that villages gain strategic autonomy rather than permanent dependence on the Park.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will reframe the Agro-Park as a failing state and the villages as startup nations. Experiments at village level will be about alternative currencies, land trusts, and circular economies, effectively prototyping new micro-polities. We will then support a diplomatic corps from these startups to negotiate with the Park as peers, not as beneficiaries seeking alignment.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will orchestrate a policy pilgrimage where Agro-Park planners live and work alongside experimenting villages for extended periods as ordinary labourers, not observers. The intention is to transform their mental models so deeply that future policy is written from an embodied village perspective, dissolving the need for external alignment.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will establish a playful but serious ministry of ungovernance within the community, whose purpose is to think through breaking every rule in the Park policy in thought experiments and to discern what becomes more alive when each rule is set aside. This helps the community clarify its own compass and engage with the Park from a place of deep principle rather than mere compliance or rejection.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will lean into the tension between rigid policy and free experimentation and hold it publicly as a creative paradox. Through art, ritual, and deep dialogue, we will invite the emergence of a third concept that transcends both Agro-Park and village experiment, such as a bioregional covenant, and then put our energy into manifesting that new form so the original dichotomy becomes obsolete.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will treat the Agro-Park policy as a poem rather than a rigid legal text, inviting multiple valid interpretations. Village experiments will be performative interpretations of lines in that poem, with one village emphasising efficiency as human rest and another as ecological health. Alignment then becomes an ongoing, plural artistic practice rather than a fixed compliance checklist.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will help communities build such strong, experiment-driven enterprises that they are eventually able to organise a cooperative bid to buy the Agro-Park infrastructure itself, flipping the ownership structure. In this vision, every experiment is a stepping stone toward eventual community ownership rather than better compliance with someone else’s asset.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will advocate for the end of fixed policy by making the case that, in a volatile climate, what we need is a portfolio of legitimised, funded experiments instead of static plans. Our villages then become nodes in a national network of experiments from which evolving guidance is drawn, replacing the idea of balancing experimentation with policy with a new paradigm of policy emerging from experimentation.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will use the community as a sensorium for the unconscious of the Agro-Park policy. We will design experiments that deliberately surface the policy’s hidden fears and desires, such as fear of disorder or desire for modernity, and then use the insights from these experiments to facilitate deeper psychological negotiation between policy makers and communities beyond surface-level alignment.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will build a time machine for Park planners using experiential futures. We will immerse them in embodied simulations of different futures, including one where rigid policies fail disastrously and one where mutual experimentation thrives, and let the emotional impact of these experiences reorient our collective approach to Agro-Park design and village innovation.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will convene a truth and reconciliation process between the idea of policy and the idea of experimentation, personifying each as a character with grievances and fears. Through public testimony, apology, and covenant-making, we will symbolically heal the relationship at narrative level so that future Agro-Park and village decisions are made in a different emotional field.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will negotiate that any community engaging with the Agro-Park must present a portfolio of live experiments as proof of its adaptability and creativity, and in turn the Park must present experiments in equity and governance. Mutual experimentation becomes the basic currency of trust so that neither side is static and the idea of pilot theatre loses meaning.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will embed the Agro-Park inside the village’s spiritual ecology by working with ritual leaders to ritually marry the Park to the spirit of the land. In such a frame, experiments are offerings that explore how to honour that marriage, and alignment is judged against sacred, not just bureaucratic, criteria.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will run a dual-power strategy openly by building two systems in parallel: an official Park-facing system that meets formal requirements and a shadow commonwealth that builds community sovereignty through experimentation. Communities will be invited to learn the rules of the official system partly in order to subvert and repurpose them for the shadow system over time.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will treat the strictest Agro-Park requirements as creative constraints for a community-wide innovation challenge, inviting people to ask how they can meet those constraints while dramatically improving other values like biodiversity or women’s leisure time. Policy becomes the frame for deeper creativity rather than a ceiling on imagination.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will ally with reform-minded officials inside the Ministry and use evidence from village experiments to help them craft a counter-policy stream within government. Our villages become living proof for this insurgent policy, and our goal is not to balance with the existing Agro-Park framework but to eventually replace it with something more just and experimental.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will broaden the definition of village to include soils, water, and other species, and design experiments that explicitly serve multi-species flourishing. We will then demand that Agro-Park policy be evaluated on its impact on this whole community of life, making conventional human-centred alignment impossible and forcing a new ecological policy logic.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: We will lean into the idea of theatre by intentionally making the early engagement with the Agro-Park a deep, co-created performance in which villagers and officials rehearse an ideal relationship through scripted and improvised scenes. By performing this relationship with emotional truth, over time the actors may be transformed and the scripted possibility may become the lived reality, turning pilot theatre into a vehicle for genuine change.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: I'd give them cheaper plastic bags to put their maize in. I'd judge it by whether they use the bags. If they don't, I would conclude they are ungrateful rather than reviewing the idea.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: We will test having them walk to the market in a group for safety. I will judge it by whether they complain less about transportation costs, not by any actual impact on prices or access.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: My innovation is to tell them to sell to their neighbours first instead of the market. I will judge success by a reduction in the amount they bring to the formal market, even if that means less visibility and lower overall income.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: We will provide a handwritten signboard for their selling point. If the sign is still hanging there after a week, I will call it a success, regardless of whether it attracted any customers or changed sales.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: We will test a bulk discount where if they all sell to one trader, they get a slightly better price. I will judge it purely by whether the trader agrees, not by how it affects women’s bargaining power or dependence.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: The frugal innovation is to use their children as messengers to find buyers. I will judge it by whether the children run the errands without demanding payment, ignoring any impact on their safety or schooling.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: We will have them pool money to buy a single bicycle. I will judge it by whether they fight over who uses it first; if there is no fight, I will assume the innovation worked, regardless of whether they actually reach better markets.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: We will test a market-day text-message reminder to tell them when to go. I will judge it by whether they have their phones turned on, not by whether messages help them reach buyers or improve timing.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: My innovation is to use old newspapers as packaging instead of buying bags. I will judge it by whether buyers reject the produce as dirty, rather than checking if it adds value or meets hygiene standards.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: We will get them a shared ledger book to track sales. I will judge it by whether the book gets lost within the week, instead of asking what they learned from using it or how it affected their record-keeping confidence.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: We will test asking them to smile more at customers as the innovation. I will judge it by whether they report any increase in sales, and if they do not, I will blame their attitude rather than the idea.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: The frugal idea is to sell slightly damaged produce at a lower price instead of throwing it away. I will judge it by whether they feel ashamed doing it, not by whether it recovers any value or reduces waste.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: We will have them sing a song to attract customers at the stall. I will judge it simply by whether anyone stops to listen, without looking at sales or whether the women feel comfortable performing.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: We will test using a shared umbrella for shade at the market. I will judge it by whether the umbrella breaks within the week, not by whether it improves the condition and presentation of their produce or comfort.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: My innovation is to appoint the loudest woman as the group's market promoter. I will judge it by whether the others get jealous and stop cooperating, rather than by any actual increase in customers or sales.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: We will give them a piece of chalk to write prices on the ground in front of their stall. I will judge it by whether it rains and washes the prices away, instead of tracking whether buyers find the prices clearer or fairer.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: We will test a buy-one-get-one-free offer on very small items. I will judge it by whether they end up giving away too much and making a loss, not by whether it brings in new customers or can be refined.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: The frugal fix is to have them take turns staying late at the market to sell leftovers. I will judge it only by whether the woman on duty gets home safely, without considering whether the extra hours make any financial sense.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: We will use a community leader's loudspeaker to announce that their produce is for sale. I will judge it by whether the leader decides to charge them for the service, not by how many new customers show up.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: We will test nothing at all because I believe market access is not about innovation, it is only about hard work. I will judge them solely based on how much they sell, regardless of conditions or support.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a shared, laminated price list for common produce so all women quote consistent prices. I would judge it by surveying a few women at the end of the week to see if they used it and whether they felt it reduced buyer haggling.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a simple, colour-coded tagging system, such as a green ribbon for organic and a red ribbon for standard produce, to differentiate their goods. I would judge it by observing whether customers ask about the tags and whether women can explain them confidently.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: using a shared WhatsApp group to quickly inform each other which trader is offering the best price on a given market day. I would judge it by counting how many price alerts are shared over the week and interviewing a few members on how useful they found the information.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: creating a collective brand by stamping their maize sacks with a shared, hand-carved logo. I would judge it by checking whether any buyers comment on or recognise the stamp by the end of the week and whether women feel more visible as a group.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: introducing a rotating role of market scout, where one woman goes early to survey prices and reports back to the group before they sell. I would judge it by checking whether the scout role was filled all week and whether the reported prices actually influenced where and when others sold.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: providing a shared handheld digital scale to ensure accurate weighing and build trust with buyers. I would judge it by monitoring how often the scale is used, asking a couple of buyers if they noticed or appreciated it, and checking if women feel more confident in price discussions.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: issuing a basic, pre-printed certificate of origin for their village that they can show to buyers interested in traceability. I would judge it by distributing a small batch of certificates, tracking how many were presented to buyers, and collecting buyer feedback on whether it mattered to them.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: building a mobile display stand from reclaimed wood and crates to present their produce more attractively. I would judge it by observing whether the stand is used consistently, taking simple before-and-after photos, and asking women if they felt it drew more customers to their stall.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: purchasing a shared solar charger for their phones so they can reliably communicate with buyers. I would judge it by tracking how many women used the charger during the week and gathering any examples where it helped avoid missed calls or lost orders.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: introducing a simple recording system in the group notebook where they track each buyer's preferences, such as preferred size or variety. I would judge it by reviewing the notes at week’s end and asking whether anyone used that information to prepare produce or target sales differently.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: pooling resources to buy a large shared tarp to protect their produce from sun and dust at the market. I would judge it by observing whether it is used regularly and asking if the women felt it improved the appearance or shelf life of their produce.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: agreeing on a short, standard sales pitch that they all practise, emphasising quality and climate-smart practices. I would judge it by listening to a few women deliver the pitch at market and noting buyer reactions and whether sellers feel more confident explaining their value.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: using natural, locally available leaves such as banana leaves as biodegradable packaging for small vegetable portions. I would judge it by seeing whether buyers accept the packaging, whether it reduces the need for plastic, and whether women find it practical to prepare.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: placing a small customer feedback jar at the stall with paper slips where buyers can drop suggestions. I would judge it by counting the number of slips at the end of the week, reading the comments with the group, and seeing whether any actionable ideas emerge.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: coordinating their arrival so they occupy adjacent stalls, creating a stronger visual presence in the market. I would judge it by observing whether they manage to cluster stalls and asking if they felt this increased foot traffic or made them more noticeable to buyers.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: establishing a small shared float of change that all sellers can draw on to give exact change to customers. I would judge it by tracking whether the float is used and replenished and asking if it helped speed up transactions or prevented lost sales.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: developing a basic pictorial guide to common produce defects so they can grade their harvest into premium and standard lots. I would judge it by checking whether sorted produce attracted different prices and whether women found the guide easy to use.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: using a local community radio announcement slot to advertise the group’s presence at the next market day. I would judge it by asking new customers how they heard about the stall and tracking any sales they attribute to the radio message.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: introducing a simple loyalty card system where regular buyers receive a stamp each time they purchase and get a small bonus after several stamps. I would judge it by distributing a small number of cards, tracking how many are stamped during the week, and asking whether buyers return more often.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: constructing a basic rain shelter from poles and thatch for their market space to protect produce. I would judge it by whether it is used during a rain shower, whether it prevents spoilage, and whether women feel it improves their comfort and willingness to stay at the market.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a frugal blockchain-ledger-by-hand. We create a simple communal ledger where each sale is recorded with seller, buyer, quantity, price, and a reciprocal thumbprint from the buyer, using carbonless copy paper so the buyer keeps a copy. I would judge it by the percentage of group sales recorded during the week, the number of buyers willing to add their thumbprint, and whether the ledger is actually used to resolve any disputes about price or quantity.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: the silent auction tarp. At the market the group spreads a large tarp and each woman places her produce with a hidden minimum price written on a stone underneath. Buyers place bids by putting money next to the items they want. I would judge it by comparing achieved prices to typical haggled prices, tracking women’s reported stress levels, and counting how many buyers participate in this non-verbal auction format.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a mobile market micro-franchise. One woman gets a standardised market-in-a-box kit and acts as a commissioned sales agent for several women who cannot travel. I would judge it by the volume she sells on behalf of others, the prices those absentee sellers receive compared to going themselves, and whether her small commission covers her costs so the model is sustainable.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a pre-commitment purchase club with local bulk buyers such as schools or eateries, where they commit to buy a set quantity weekly for a month. Simple SMS confirmations handle each week. I would judge it by the share of buyers who sign up, how much it smooths women’s weekly income, and how much it reduces unsold produce at the end of market days.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a concentrated quality-incentive flash mob, where for one market day the women coordinate to bring only their highest quality produce to a single branded stall as a premium popup. I would judge it by the price premium achieved over normal days, buyer perceptions of quality, and whether women internalise the value of differentiated quality after seeing the results.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a barter exchange network at the market using a simple board where women and others can post what they have and what they need, enabling multilateral swaps instead of only cash sales. I would judge it by the number of successful non-cash transactions, women’s perceptions of fairness in those swaps, and whether the network connects them to new trading partners they did not know before.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a predictive market oracle in which women use beans as tokens to bet on the price of maize at the end of the week, collectively creating a price forecast. I would judge it by how close their prediction comes to actual prices and whether participating women adjust their selling strategy, such as choosing when to sell, based on the shared forecast.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a reputation token system where women give small handmade beads to buyers after a positive, fair transaction, turning those beads into a visible trust signal. I would judge it by how many tokens circulate, whether bead-holding buyers return more often, and whether women feel more confident opening conversations by referring to the trust beads.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: an embedded market researcher, where an adolescent girl is trained as a mystery shopper to visit competing stalls, gather intelligence on prices, quality, and tactics, and brief the women’s group each evening. I would judge it by the number of concrete insights she brings, the extent to which women change their behaviour in response, and whether the process strengthens youth inclusion and intergenerational learning.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a dynamic pricing flag system using simple coloured flags at the stall to signal stock levels and pricing stance, such as green for plenty, yellow for limited, and red for almost sold out. I would judge it by buyer reactions and foot traffic under each flag, effects on how quickly inventory sells, and how well the group coordinates when to change flags.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a co-opetition pact between women selling different products, where they actively refer customers to one another instead of competing in isolation. I would judge it by counting referrals, monitoring any increase in cross-sales, and checking whether the relationships and trust between different product groups strengthen over the week.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a prescriptive analytics chalkboard near the market entrance where each morning one woman posts three simple recommendations drawn from last week’s sales patterns, such as suggested bundles. I would judge it by how many women try the tips, comparing sales of those who do and do not, and whether others start contributing their own insights to the board.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a negotiation role-play dojo where, before market, women practise short, intense negotiation scenarios with one another, simulating tough buyers and exploring responses. I would judge it by changes in self-reported confidence, observed differences in how they handle real haggling, and whether they are able to hold closer to their minimum prices.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: creating a physical, low-tech digital twin of the market using cloth and stones to map buyer types, price zones, and stall locations, updated daily by the women. I would judge it by whether anyone changes their stall position or target buyers based on the map, whether it helps them anticipate where the best prices will be, and whether the group uses it in collective planning.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a simple escrow service for large, risky transactions where a trusted local shopkeeper holds mobile money until the buyer confirms delivery. I would judge it by the number of high-value deals completed without dispute, whether it gives women the confidence to engage with new or distant buyers, and whether all parties find the small fee acceptable for reduced risk.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a why-I-farm story card attached to each woman’s produce, with a simple photo and one sentence about her motivation, to humanise the transaction. I would judge it by whether buyers notice and comment on the cards, any observed price or loyalty effects, and whether women feel more pride and connection in telling their stories.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a gamified sales challenge where women earn points for trying new tactics, reaching new buyers, or achieving better prices, with a small prize at the end. I would judge it by the number of new behaviours attempted, how quickly effective tactics spread among the group, and how engaged and energised the women feel during the week.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: using a one-page lean value-chain canvas to map the journey of a single product from field to buyer, highlighting where time, cost, and value are lost. I would judge it by whether they identify at least one non-obvious bottleneck, whether they try a concrete fix within the week, and whether this exercise shifts their sense of agency over the chain.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a market stress-test simulation where we announce a hypothetical glut of cheap maize arriving tomorrow, then observe and support their responses. I would judge it by the diversity and quality of strategies they try, the prices they actually achieve under perceived stress, and the robustness of contingency plans they co-create in the debrief.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: an invisible market maker test where one woman offers a lightly processed product such as pre-washed, chopped vegetables at a modest premium to see if there is demand for convenience. I would judge it by how fast this product sells relative to raw produce, whether the premium covers extra labour and yields higher net income, and whether others are eager to replicate the model.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a ritual of the first sale, a one-minute sacred practice each morning where the women touch the earth, stand in silence, and set an intention for dignified and joyful trade. I would judge it by qualitative shifts in how they describe market interactions, observers’ sense of their collective coherence, and stories from buyers about the changed atmosphere around their stall.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a gift economy stall where, for one week, women give their best produce freely to anyone who needs it and receive only non-cash gifts in return. I would judge it by the circulation and diversity of non-monetary value, observable changes in community relationships, and the extent to which this experiment disturbs conventional ideas about markets and poverty.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a land-as-senior-partner contract where the women draft and symbolically sign an agreement committing a portion of sales to caring for the land, then show this contract to buyers. I would judge it by how many buyers voluntarily accept a land premium, whether the group creates a real land stewardship role, and whether this story changes how both sides talk about value and responsibility.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a reverse market where, instead of going to town, the women host buyers on the farm for a shared harvest, meal, and storytelling experience in which buying food is only one element. I would judge it by the total value of sales combined with the perceived value of the experience, the depth of ongoing relationships that form, and whether buyers leave with a fundamentally different understanding of food and labour.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a time bank for market labour where, instead of paying each other cash, women bank and exchange hours of help for tasks like transport, stall setup, and sales support. I would judge it by how actively hour credits circulate, whether time-poor women can access support through past deposits, and whether tensions about who does the hard work ease as cooperation is decommodified.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: an algorithm of enough, a simple rule that they stop selling once each member has earned what she defines as enough for her family’s weekly needs, with any surplus given away, saved, or reinvested in the land. I would judge it by whether they actually honour this stopping rule, how it affects anxiety and scarcity feelings, and how buyers react when sellers step back after reaching sufficiency.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a multispecies sales force where children and friendly dogs, adorned with playful symbols of the group, are part of the stall’s presence, using song and play to draw people in. I would judge it by the joy level at the stall, how this blurs boundaries between work and play, and whether it attracts a different, more open kind of customer engagement.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a debt-for-nature swap stall where each kilogram sold is symbolically framed as forgiving a unit of ecological debt owed by industrial agriculture, tracked on a public tally. I would judge it by the depth of conversations it sparks about food systems, whether women begin to see themselves as creditors rather than supplicants, and whether this framing seeds a politics of repair.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a market-as-temple-of-data sovereignty experiment where buyers pay primarily for the story and data about the crop, with the physical food as a bonus. I would judge it by whether anyone pays more for the narrative than the produce, whether buyers start valuing information differently, and whether women feel a stronger sense of owning their data as the real asset.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: an un-market week where women boycott the physical marketplace and instead hold daily dreaming circles to imagine an entirely new food distribution system beyond competitive stalls. I would judge it by the boldness and coherence of the models they design, the solidarity built through the boycott, and the reaction of traders and officials confronted with this refusal to play by the usual rules.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: an ancestral vendor possession day where elder women channel ancestral voices to set prices and accept symbolic payments instead of cash. I would judge it by how powerful and authentic participants experience the ritual to be, the richness of non-cash exchanges that flow, and whether people sense a collapse of past and present in the marketplace.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a holographic cooperative using a cheap phone and cloth screen to project a live video of a woman selling in a distant urban market right beside local sellers with the same produce, coordinating prices and messaging in real time. I would judge it by whether local prices move closer to urban prices, whether the urban–rural hierarchy feels challenged, and whether both sellers feel part of one shared field rather than separate worlds.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a metabolic rift repair kit in which the women sell a service to install closed-loop food systems in customers' homes so they no longer need to buy produce, essentially selling their own obsolescence. I would judge it by the number of such packages sold, the success of installed systems in creating buyer independence, and the depth of reflection it provokes in the women about building livelihoods by making themselves unnecessary.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: an empathy pricing experiment where, before naming a price, the seller spends a couple of minutes listening to a personal challenge in the buyer’s life and then adjusts the price based on the buyer’s self-reported emotional burden. I would judge it by the depth of sharing it elicits, whether this practice nudges resources toward those struggling more, and whether buyers feel emotionally lighter after the exchange.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a mycelial currency experiment where packets of beneficial fungal spores are used as a parallel medium of exchange alongside cash. I would judge it by whether any actual transactions occur in spores, whether the practice improves soil health over time, and whether it helps people think of money as something living that nourishes ecosystems.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a market somatics workshop before selling, where women locate and gently release the bodily tension tied to past exploitation in markets, then enter the day from a more grounded state. I would judge it by observable shifts in posture and presence, changes in how buyers respond to their boundaries, and women’s reports of feeling cleaner and more whole in the act of selling.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a polycentric pricing council in which a rotating group of community members, not just sellers, sets a single fair price for each product each day based on community needs and ecological costs. I would judge it by whether both buyers and sellers accept the price as legitimate, the quality of the council’s deliberations, and the experience of non-sellers in wielding economic decision-making power.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a transgressive subsidy practice where women sell at deliberately low prices but verbally name the hidden subsidies underpinning that low price, such as unpaid care work or ecological damage elsewhere. I would judge it by the cognitive dissonance it triggers in buyers, how widely the story spreads, and whether it helps the women articulate a shared political analysis of the food system.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: a live philosophy debate at the stall where one woman argues for the virtues of the market and another for the virtues of the gift economy while produce itself is free, and bystanders can financially support whichever argument they find more convincing. I would judge it by the level of engagement and depth of the debates, the flow of funds toward each side, and how the women’s own economic thinking evolves.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Innovation: an offering to the unknown where each woman brings her finest produce and places it on a communal altar with a note saying it is for whoever needs it most, with no monitoring of who takes it. I would judge it by the group’s ability to tolerate not knowing, any shifts in their sense of abundance versus scarcity, and the myths or stories that emerge in the community about where the food went.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: I claim to own everything across supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation. I do not name any other owners or handoff points; the only milestone I recognize is not getting fired.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: The formal partner owns all supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation; we simply outsource responsibility. The only milestone that matters to me is that they submit a report, regardless of its quality or timing.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: Kujenga as an organisation can figure out all aspects of execution because they are the so-called grassroots experts; I do not name any specific people or milestones. My only indicator is that they eventually stop complaining, not whether the work is coherent or effective.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: We will put all these functions into a RACI chart once, assign generic roles, and then never look at it again. The milestone I am focused on is simply that the chart is created, not that it is used to guide real-time execution.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: Ownership of supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation will go to whoever shouts loudest in the meeting. The milestone is that the meeting ends without clear or fair assignments, even if everyone leaves confused.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: I assume the ownership of all these functions is hidden somewhere in the original proposal, so I will not actively map or update it. My only milestone is to find the old proposal document, not to create a living execution spine.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: We will rotate ownership of supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation every week to be so-called fair, without considering continuity or competence. The resulting milestone is that everyone becomes confused about who is responsible at any point in time.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: I say the donor owns everything because they are paying for the project, including the supply-chain, MEAL, community liaison, and escalation decisions. My only milestone is keeping the donor satisfied superficially, not ensuring internal clarity or community alignment.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: I avoid naming specific people for supply-chain, MEAL, community liaison, or escalation because I think names create accountability and blame. The milestone is that no one is clearly accountable, so no single person can be challenged when things go wrong.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: I put the most junior staff member in charge of tracking everything while I personally reserve decision-making; I do not give them authority or support. The milestone is that the junior staff member burns out while I stay distant from day-to-day execution issues.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: We will rely on an AI tool to randomly assign owners for supply-chain engagement, MEAL, community liaison, and escalation without human judgment. The milestone in my mind is just that the tool is installed, not that the assignments make sense or are accepted by people.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: I insist that ownership is purely collective across all functions, so nobody is specifically responsible for supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, liaison, or escalation. The milestone is that we proudly state shared ownership, even though it results in nothing actually getting done when issues arise.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: I say the government owns the entire execution spine now because we are aligning with Agro-Parks, so we abdicate our role in supply-chain, MEAL, liaison, and escalation. The milestone becomes that the government forgets about us or does nothing, while we disclaim responsibility.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: I will delegate everything to a committee that nominally owns supply-chain, MEAL, liaison, and escalation but meets infrequently and has no power. The milestone I recognise is that the committee meets once so we can say it exists, even if it never follows up on anything.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: I assign ownership to whoever has the fanciest job title across supply-chain, MEAL, community liaison, and escalation, without checking capacity or interest. The main milestone, from my point of view, is that the titles are printed on an organogram, not that owners are functional.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: We will not assign clear owners until something fails; then we will pick someone to fix that piece in a reactive manner. The milestone I implicitly use is the first visible failure, not proactive mapping of the execution spine.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: I treat the execution spine as a purely theoretical concept to talk about in workshops, not as a concrete map with real people and milestones. The only milestone is that the theory has been discussed, even if no practical changes follow.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: Each department will own its own piece of the work, such as supply or M&E, but nobody will own the connections or handoffs between them. The milestone is that strong silos are built and defended, even if overall execution breaks down at the boundaries.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: We will assign ownership based on who travels to the field the least, prioritising convenience over effectiveness. The milestone becomes that no one travels to the field and the spine is managed remotely, detached from community realities.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: We will wait until the project is over and then map the execution spine only as part of a lessons-learned exercise. The milestone I care about is the project end, not shaping real-time ownership or escalation paths during implementation.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.

The milestone is that all these roles are confirmed in a joint kick-off meeting by the end of Week 2.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.

The milestone is that their job descriptions are updated to include these specific responsibilities.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
